monster_01.name: Angry Guppy
monster_01.desc: A guppy that woke up on the wrong side of the riverbed this morning.

monster_02.name: Bad-Tempered Crawdad
monster_02.desc: Has tattoos on his shell indicating he's a member of the 'Big Bad Daddy' gang. He also has one depicting a scantily-clad salmon. What an unsavory fellow!

monster_03.name: Freshwater Sea Cucumber
monster_03.desc: Sea cucumbers serve a useful role in the marine ecosystem as they help recycle nutrients, breaking down detritus and other organic matter after which bacteria can continue the degradation process. They are also quick with a blade. Watch out!

monster_04.name: Juvenille Flagtail
monster_04.desc: Looks like he just finished spray-painting graffiti on an elderly fish's dorsal fin. Dang kids and their punk rock music. If you had a lawn, he would surely not be welcome on it.

monster_05.name: Scurvy Sea Dog
monster_05.desc: You thought this was just a thing that pirates said. Nope! It's real, and it's currently fighting you.

monster_06.name: Grouchy Hermit Crab
monster_06.desc: This crab appears to be fed up with people knocking on his shell and asking him for advice. He's ready to give you a piece of his mind. And by "mind" he means "pincers."

monster_07.name: Emo Eel
monster_07.desc: This eel is just...man. Nobody understand his pain, you know? Ugh. It's just like, I mean, I don't even...just...ugh. Spends his days working as a Sand Bar-ista.

monster_08.name: Vengeful Clownfish
monster_08.desc: This is the part they didn't show you in the movie. His name is Nemo. [He thinks] you killed his mother. Prepare to die!

monster_09.name: Samurai Salmon
monster_09.desc: Like most salmon, he was born in fresh water, migrated to the ocean, and is now returning to his birthplace. Unlike other salmon, however, this one spent his time in the ocean learning how to dual-wield katanas. Different strokes for different folks, I guess.

monster_10.name: Hungry Alligator
monster_10.desc: Possibly a crocodile. That's not important, though, because they both have a lot of teeth, and they're all sharp as hell. I would not want to mess with one of these wingless sea dragons, if I were you.

monster_11.name: Zebra Archerfish
monster_11.desc: Did you know that Archerfish can bring down insects and other prey up to 3 meters above the water's surface? I'm not sure what 3 meters translates to in normal-person units, but I'm guessing it's a lot more impressive than that super-soaker you got when you were a kid. I really hope more fish don't learn how to turn their faces into guns, or we're going to have some real problems on our hands, real fast.

monster_12.name: Confused Elk
monster_12.desc: What the--?! This is a LAND MAMMAL! How did this get in here!? I mean, this is a game about fish and other aquatic creatures. Not a game about freakin' moose! Mooses? Moo--you know what, just...just fight it anyway. Whatever. I'm going to go find a dictionary.

monster_13.name: Marine Iguana
monster_13.desc: These reptiles are usually black or grey. They are between 20 and 34 cm long, have laterally flattened tails, spiky dorsal fins, and long sharp claws. Interestingly enough, Charles Darwin called them "disgusting clumsy Lizards." Even MORE interesting than that, however, is that he ALSO called them "imps of darkness." So...yeah, have fun fighting that.

monster_14.name: Well-Armed Coconut Octopus
monster_14.desc: Each arm of this invertebrate has dozens of small suckers, and each one of the suckers is clutching a tiny knife. You do not know where he got so many tiny knifes. Perhaps he had them custom-made?

monster_15.name: Pacific Sea Nettle Jellyfish
monster_15.desc: Sea nettles have a distinctive golden-brown bell with a reddish tint. The bell can grow to be larger than one meter in diameter in the wild, though most are less than 50 cm across. The long, spiraling, white oral arms and the 24 undulating maroon tentacles may trail behind as far as 15 feet. For humans, its sting is often irritating, but rarely dangerous. You're about to find out what happens to sturgeons, however.
